folder.title: CHIRPS
folder.description: Climate Hazard group InfraRed Precipitation with Stations (CHIRPS) is a global (50° S - 50° N, 180° E - 180° W), 0.05° resolution, 1981 to near-present gridded precipitation time series. CHIRPS data are produced by scientists at the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB) Climate Hazard Group (CHG) and the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center. See CHIRPS web page for more information.

folder.title: CHIRPS-GEFS Forecast
folder.description: CHIRPS-GEFS is a product that combines the NCEP's Global Ensemble Forecast System (GEFS) 16 day precipitation forecasts with the CHIRPS climatology to produce a CHIRPS compatible (latitude 50N - 50S, ~0.05 degree resolution) dekadal forecasts. Precipitation forecasts are produced daily and accumulated for the 10 day forecast period beginning on the date in the title bar.

folder.title: CHIRTSmax
folder.description:
Climate Hazard group InfraRed Temperature with Stations maximum (CHIRTSmax) is a beta version of global (60° S - 70° N, 180° E - 180° W), 0.05° resolution, 1983 to near-present gridded maximum temperature time series. CHIRTSmax data are produced by scientists at the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB) Climate Hazard Group (CHG) and the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center.
See CHG web page for more information.

folder.title: MODIS LST
folder.description:
MODIS LST is the Land Surface Temperature measured by the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer launched in May 2002 on board the Aqua satellite. EWX aquires 0.05 x 0.05 degree spatial resolution MODIS LST

Daily: MODIS/Aqua Land Surface Temperature/Emissivity Daily L3 Global 0.05Deg CMG V005 and

Monthly: MODIS/Aqua Land Surface Temperature/Emissivity Monthly L3 Global 0.05Deg CMG V005

data using NASA's WIST server. The daily data is averaged into dekads, the monthly data is used to create the 2-monthly and 3-monthly data. Individual observations are subtracted from the time series mean to produce anomaly data. Zscores are determined by dividing the anomaly by the standard deviation over the available data.

All three products, data, anomaly and zscores are converted to GeoTiffs to be ingested into EWX.

Questions?

About the Data: email Pete Peterson
About EWX: email Michael Budde

folder.title: CHIRPS-Prelim
folder.description:
Climate Hazard group InfraRed Precipitation with Stations (CHIRPS) is a global (50° S - 50° N, 180° E - 180° W), 0.05° resolution, 1981 to near-present gridded precipitation time series. The Preliminary version is produced 2 days after every pentad of the month and contains fewer station values than the final version produced monthly.
See CHIRPS web page for more information.

folder.title: sMODIS NDVI
folder.description: The reNDVI product is calculated from the Collection 6 Terra MODIS 250 m daily surface reflectance product MOD09GQ.006 (Vermote and Wolfe, 2015b). Processing steps for the reNDVI dataset include quality filtering of pixels, calculation of NDVI, compositing over a 10-day period, filling low quality pixels with climatology data, despiking, and finally temporal smoothing. Generate stats for Kenya Admin 3 layer and other Kenya related polygons.

folder.name: sndvi:sndvi_africa_1-dekad-{{period}}-{{year}}_ndvi_data
folder.title: Dekadal
folder.description: Smoothed MODIS NDVI at 250 meters resolution for Kenya

folder.title: LULC 2000-2017
folder.description: These datasets represent yearly land cover maps from 2000 to 2017 for the East African nations of Zambia, Malawi, Tanzania, Rwanda, Kenya, Uganda, and Ethiopia. The map legend corresponds to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) land categories for reporting of greenhouse gas emissions: Forest land, Grassland, Cropland, Wetlands, Settlement, and Other land. These datasets were created using the Continuous Change Detection and Classification (CCDC) algorithm on the Google Earth Engine. CCDC uses time series analysis of Landsat data to monitor for land cover or condition change at 30 meter spatial resolution. This project was supported by the NASA SERVIR Applied Science Team, the Regional Centre for Mapping of Resources for Development, the NASA SERVIR Science Coordination Office, the US Agency for International Development, and the USGS SilvaCarbon program.

folder.title: DomCat_June_2017
folder.description: Estimates of high groundwater use by volume (vol) for domestic (dom) needs (35+ L / person / day). This has been defined as categorical (cat): greater than 35 L (raster value = 1) or less than 35 L (raster value = 0). Estimates were conducted during the dry season (June-Sep), since this is the period when populations are most likely to rely on ground water to meet their basic needs.

folder.title: DomProb_June_2017
folder.description: Estimates of high groundwater use by volume (vol) for domestic (dom) needs (35+ L / person / day) given in terms of the probability (prob) of being in the higher use category (35+L/person/day). The higher the probability the more likely the population is using groundwater to meet domestic water needs.
